item.label: Diencephalon
item.name: Diencephalon
item.description: Developmentally, the diencephalon and telencephalon are derived from the most anterior aspect of the developing neural tube, i.e. the prosencephalon. It includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus. The retina, optic nerve and tract and neurohypophysis are also considered to be part of the diencephalon since they are formed as outgrowths from the diencephalon.

item.label: Thalamus
item.name: Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Lateral geniculate nucleus
item.name: Lateral geniculate body
item.description: The lateral geniculate thalamic nucleus (LGN) deals with vision.  It receives input from the retina via the optic nerve and tract. It projects to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe (cuneus and lingual gyri) via the geniculocalcarine tract.  The geniculocalcarine tract is AKA the optic radiation and travels in both the sublenticular and retrolentricular portions of the internal capsule.

item.label: Medial geniculate nucleus
item.name: Medial geniculate body
item.description: The medial geniculate thalamic nucleus (MGN) deals with hearing.  It receives input from the cochlea via the cochlear nuclei, lateral lemniscus and inferior colliculus. It projects to primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe (transverse temporal or Heschl's gyri) via the sublenticular part of the internal capsule.

item.label: Epithalamus, Habenula
item.name: Habenula
item.description: The habenula is a small bump or mound on the dorsomedial surface of the caudal thalamus.  it is formed by the underlying habenular nuclei.  It is part of the epithalamus.

item.label: Epithalamus, Pineal gland
item.name: Pineal gland
item.description: The pineal gland is the part of the epithalamus that extends caudally from the area of the habenular nuclei and into the superior cistern, immediately dorsal to the superior colliculi. As an endocrine gland, it secretes melatonin and is involved with circadian rhythms and the sleep-wake cycle.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Superior colliculus
item.name: Superior colliculus
item.description: The superior colliculi are paired, rounded structures on the superior surface of the rostral midbrain formed by the laminated or layered nuclei of the superior colliculi. Along with the paired inferior colliculi in the caudal midbrain, they form the tectum or roof of the midbrain and are collectively referred to as the corpora quadrigemina. The superior colliculus receives input from the retina and visual cortex and sends its output to the pulvinar of the thalamus, and plays a role in controlling eye movements, etc..

item.label: Superior brachium
item.name: Superior brachium
item.description: The brachium of the superior colliculus is AKA the superior brachium. It is a band of nerve fibers carrying information to the superior colliculus and pretectal area from the retina and visual cerebral cortex.

item.label: Inferior colliculus
item.name: Inferior colliculus
item.description: The inferior colliculi are paired rounded structures on the superior surface of the caudal midbrain formed by the paired nuclei of the inferior colliculus.  Along with the paired superior colliculi in the rostral midbrain, they form the tectum or roof of the midbrain and are collectively referred to as the corpora quadrigemina. The inferior colliculus is an important synapse in the auditory pathway, receiving auditory input from the lateral lemniscus and sending its output via the brachium of the inferior colliculus to synapse in the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.

item.label: Inferior brachium
item.name: Inferior brachium
item.description: The brachium of the inferior colliculus is AKA the inferior brachium. It is a band of nerve fibers carrying auditory input from the inferior colliculus of the midbrain to the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus. It is clearly visible grossly on the lateral aspect of the midbrain.

item.label: Cerebral crus
item.name: Cerbral crus
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Trochlear nerve
item.name: Trochlear nerve
item.description: The fourth or trochlear cranial nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye. It is the only cranial nerve to exit the dorsal aspect of the brainstem. This location is just caudal to the inferior colliculi of the midbrain.

item.label: Pons
item.name: Pons
item.description: The pons is that portion of the brainstem between the midbrain and medulla. It consists of a basilar or basal portion that contains structures primarily associated with motor control and a tegmental portion that contains cranial nerve nuclei and important sensory tracts. The cerebellum overlies the pons and medulla. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on the dorsal surface of the pons. The pons and cerebellum originate embryologically from the metencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Superior cerebellar peduncle
item.name: Cerebellar peduncle (superior)
item.description: The superior cerebellar peduncle is the major efferent path from the cerebellum. It carries information from the deep cerebellar nuclei to the contralateral motor part of thalamus (VL and VA) and to the contralateral red nucleus of the midbrain. It decussates or crosses the midline within the caudal midbrain.  While this peduncle is primarily efferent relative to the cerebellum, it does contain a significant afferent pathway, the ventral or anterior spinocerebellar tract.

item.label: Middle cerebellar peduncle
item.name: Cerebellar peduncle (middle)
item.description: The middle cerebellar peduncle consists exclusively of pontocerebellar tract fibers that take their origin from pontine nuclei in the contralateral basilar pons. Thus, it carries afferent information to cerebellum from the contralateral cerebral cortex via the corticopontine to pontine nuclei to pontocerebellar tract.

item.label: Inferior cerebellar peduncle
item.name: Cerebellar peduncle (inferior)
item.description: The inferior cerebellar peduncle is AKA the restiform body. Located on the lateral aspect of the medulla, it includes multiple tracts afferent to the cerebellum including the uncrossed dorsal or posterior spinocerebellar, cuneocerebellar, vestibulocerebellar, reticulocerebellar and crossed olivocerebellar. It also includes some cerebellar output tracts such as those projecting to the reticular formation and the vestibular nuclei.

item.label: Fourth ventricle
item.name: Fourth ventricle
item.description: The fourth ventricle is a rhomboid-shaped space located superior to the pons and medulla. The roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by the inferior and superior medullary vela plus the cerebellum. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) enters the fourth ventricle from the third ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct. CSF exits the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space via the medial foramen of Magendie, located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, and the two lateral foramina of Luschka, located at the most lateral aspect of the fourth ventricle, i.e. in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle, bilaterally.  The choroid plexus is located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, beneath the inferior medullary velum.  The choroid plexus extends outside of the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka, where it can be visualized in the subarachnoid space.

item.label: Superior medullary vellum
item.name: Superior medullary vellum
item.description: The superior medullary velum is a thin layer of white matter that stretched between the paired superior cerebellar peduncles.  Along with the superior cerebellar peduncles, it forms part of the roof of the fourth ventricle.

item.label: Medial eminence
item.name: Median eminence
item.description: The medial eminence is located in the floor of the fourth ventricle between the midline sulcus and the sulcus limitans.  This area overlies three pair of motor nuclei that make visible elevations in the ventricular surface.  These elevations are the facial colliculus (facial motor nerve fibers passing over the abducens nucleus), vagal trigone (dorsa motor nucleus of the vagus ) and hypoglossal trigone (hypoglossal nucleus).  Do not confuse with median eminence which is a portion of the ventral aspect of the hypothalamus.

item.label: Third ventricle
item.name: Third ventricle
item.description: The third ventricle is a single, narrow, vertically-oriented portion of the ventricular system.  It is located between the two halves of the thalamus and hypothalamus.
